summary: This is a declaration by Assistant U.S. Attorney A. Marie Villafaña filed in the case Jane Doe v. United States, detailing the federal investigation of Jeffrey Epstein, the non-prosecution agreement process, victim notification efforts, and interactions with victims' attorneys. It reveals the U.S. Attorney's Office deferred federal prosecution to Florida state authorities in September 2007 under an agreement that preserved victims' civil rights.

persons.name: A. Marie Villafaña
persons.context: Author of the declaration; the AUSA assigned to the Jeffrey Epstein investigation who describes victim notifications, the non-prosecution agreement negotiations, and interactions with victims' attorneys.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of federal and state investigations for using interstate commerce to induce minors into prostitution; entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office in September 2007.

persons.name: Bradley Edwards
persons.context: Attorney representing three victims (clients referred to as Jane Does); contacted the AUSA about his clients and filed the Emergency Petition/Motion in this case.

persons.name: James Eisenberg
persons.context: Attorney who represented a victim identified as 'Jane Doe #4'; his fees were paid by Jeffrey Epstein, and the AUSA notes uncertainty about whether this representation was formally terminated.

connections.description: Edwards, as attorney for victims, contacted and corresponded with Villafaña, the prosecuting AUSA, regarding victim notifications and the case resolution.
Eisenberg's legal fees for representing a victim were paid by Jeffrey Epstein, the target of the investigation.
Edwards represented victims of Epstein and filed legal motions against the U.S. government related to Epstein's prosecution agreement.
Villafaña was the lead federal prosecutor investigating Epstein and negotiated the non-prosecution agreement with Epstein's attorneys.

events.title: Federal Investigation Initiated
events.description: The FBI initiated a federal investigation at the request of the Palm Beach Police Department into allegations Jeffrey Epstein used interstate commerce to induce minors into prostitution.

events.title: State Charges Filed
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was charged by the State of Florida with solicitation of prostitution under Florida law.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Signed
events.description: Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office entered into an agreement to defer federal prosecution in favor of state prosecution, containing a confidentiality provision and preserving victims' rights to sue under federal law.

events.title: Victim Notification of Agreement
events.description: Four victims were contacted by telephone and notified of the non-prosecution agreement and its provisions preserving their civil remedy.

events.title: FBI Victim Letters Dispatched
events.description: The FBI's Victim-Witness Specialist sent notification letters to two of Bradley Edwards' clients.

events.title: Federal Victim Interview
events.description: A victim identified in the PBPD investigation was interviewed by federal agents, confirming her status as a victim of a federal offense.

events.title: Scheduled State Plea Hearing
events.description: A state plea agreement hearing for Epstein was scheduled for 8:30 a.m.; the AUSA and others attempted to notify victims, but Edwards' clients did not attend.

events.title: Receipt of Edwards' Letter
events.description: A. Marie Villafaña received a letter from Attorney Bradley Edwards (sent July 3) urging vigorous federal enforcement against Epstein but not demanding the specific relief in his later Emergency Petition.

locations: University of California at Berkeley School of Law
keyFacts: The federal investigation into Jeffrey Epstein began in 2006 at the request of the Palm Beach Police Department due to concerns about the local state attorney's handling of the case.

A non-prosecution agreement was reached between Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office in September 2007, deferring federal prosecution to Florida state authorities while preserving victims' rights to sue under federal law (18 U.S.C. § 2255).

Victim notification was a key issue; the AUSA states several victims had expressed concerns about identity exposure at trial and desired a prompt resolution, and none of Bradley Edwards' clients had expressed a desire to be consulted prior to the agreement.
Attorney James Eisenberg represented a victim, and his fees were paid by Jeffrey Epstein, the target of the investigation.

The AUSA could not include one victim in the official list provided to Epstein's counsel because, based on her prior statements to law enforcement, she could not in good faith be named in a federal indictment.
